Award.AwardTitle: CCSS-CPS: Collaborative: If Bridges can talk: Towards Autonomous Structure Health Monitoring for Civil Structure

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the research is to develop fully autonomous Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) system consisting of sensors organically integrated within the structure, free of wire leads and external power sources. Central to the proposed approach are the multi-functional piezoelectric transducer-based smart aggregates, which can transform ambient energy to electricity power, modulate useful information on stress waves for communication, and generate and receive stress waves for detection of structural defects.

Intellectually, the project will advance the knowledge regarding communication over concrete conduits through: i) Measurement-driven characterization of "smart aggregates" transceivers and concrete channels under different loading conditions, and ii) Design of modulation schemes for acoustic communications in concrete channels. The project aims to develop a holistic system solution through: i) the development of energy harvesting and storage modules, in conjunction with low-power circuits, and ii) Design and evaluation of energy-aware task scheduling.

The proposed research is expected to generate far-reaching broader impacts in science, education, and society. Our systems-based research integrates innovative research on hardware, algorithms, and architectures to enable the next generation of cyber systems. It also integrates educational activities in real-life infrastructure building, communications systems, and networking. In the near term, the basic building blocks developed for communication and energy harvesting can help extend existing wireless-based, battery powered systems, making these systems more fault tolerant and energy efficient. In the long term, the project outcomes can provide impetus for wide-spread integration of fully autonomous SHM systems as the technology matures, leading to improved public safety and reduced maintenance costs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this NSF funded project is to investigate the feasibility of, and to develop prototype designs for, wire-free and sustainable structure health monitoring (SHM) systems. At the core of the proposed solution are the multifunctional piezoelectric transducer-based smart aggregates for deployment in concrete structures without easy wire access such as embedded in bridge and roads. These smart aggregates can exchange useful information as stress waves to communicate and generate/receive energy charges to deeply embedded sensing units.

In terms of intellectual merit, in collaboration with the partner team at University of Houston specializing in smart aggregates, the team at UC Davis applied measurement driven characterization to characterize channel capacity in stress-wave communications for both single and multiple source transmissions. The team evaluated the channel capacity of Single Input and Single Output (SISO) and multi-input stress-wave communication in concrete channels based on the measurement. The result shows that the two-source channel capacity of 242 kb/sec nearly doubles that of the SISO channel at 137 kb/sec for input power as low as 19dBm.

Our team also constructed a testbed and completed several implementation and tests of efficient modulations for stress-wave communications. The results confirmed the feasibility of high spectral efficiency communication with the proposed concrete stress wave communication. Testing performance with QPSK and 16QAM through a concrete block of 6 feet in length, the results exhibit that a 16QAM system is capable of achieving bit rates above 8000 bps at 37dBV transmit voltage. The experiments show that concrete channels can serve as a realistic medium in many applications for high spectral efficiency modulation methods.

Another research outcome is the feasibility test of energy transfer through stress-wave charging technology for remotely deployed structural health monitor sensors as well as optimized waveform design for remote charging.  Energy for deeply embedded remote sensors is a practical challenge. Unlike radio frequency (RF) energy transmission that has been successful for charging remote sensors, acoustic energy transfer (AET) which can use sound stress-waves to wirelessly deliver energy to remote sensors without efficient RF radio pathway, such as in underwater, underground, or tightly sealed environment. Our team investigated optimizing stresswave signal waveform such that the received signal voltage at a desired distant location should allow energy transfer by lasting sufficiently long above a specified charging threshold, while constraining the practical power of the transmitted waveform. 

In terms of broader impact, the team integrated innovation in hardware, algorithms, and architectures that are critical to the next generation smart infrastructure systems. The positive impact of the new findings on successful migration to fully autonomous structure-health monitoring systems can lead to improved public safety at reduced costs. The project also contributed to an interdisciplinary workforce by ensuring that student researchers receive the training and the research experience necessary to lead and/or engage in integrative and team approaches to complex problems. At UC Davis, two MS students successfully completed their training and education under the auspices of this project.
